The authors took pictures of the landscapes in the figure.Full size imageConversion from 11 to 6 classesTo mitigate the challenges posed by severe class imbalance in the original 11-class land cover dataset, we restructured the labels into six aggregated categories for benchmarking purposes. Deep learning models are inherently data-driven and require sufficient representation of each class to learn discriminative features effectively. However, as shown in Fig. 8a and Supplementary Table S8, several original classes such as Brick Factory (1.31% test), Road (1.02%), and Urban Structure (2.86%) constitute a very small portion of the total pixel distribution. These underrepresented classes exhibited extremely low segmentation performance, with some achieving 0.0000 IoU and F1 scores, and others, like Road, scoring only 0.0388 in IoU. Training on such imbalanced data increases the risk of bias toward majority classes and poor generalization on minority categories.To address this, semantically and spectrally similar classes were merged to form broader and more balanced high-level classes. The new Built-up class combines Urban Structure, Urban Built-up, Rural Built-up, and Brick Factory, all representing anthropogenic surfaces. Likewise, the Meadow class includes both Meadow and Marshland, which share similar spectral and contextual characteristics. In contrast, classes like Farmland, Forest, and Water were retained in their original form due to their adequate spatial coverage and distinct semantic identity. As shown in Fig. 8b and Supplementary Table S1, this restructuring significantly improved class balance and training robustness.To ensure a comprehensive evaluation, we trained and tested our models on both the original 11-class and the aggregated 6-class configurations. While the 6-class setup achieved more stable performance due to reduced class imbalance, the 11-class results are included to demonstrate model behavior under highly imbalanced conditions. Full per-class scores and distributions are provided in the supplementary figure S1.Fig. 8Area Percentage of the 11-class and 6-class dataset.Full size imageMethodologyModel architectures for LULC segmentationTo benchmark LULC segmentation performance, we evaluated three different deep learning models: DeepLabV3+, U-Net, and UniMatch. DeepLabV3+ is a state-of-the-art architecture known for its encoder-decoder design and use of atrous convolutions to capture multi-scale contextual information. U-Net is widely used for its skip connections that preserve spatial detail, making it effective for capturing fine-grained features. UniMatch, on the other hand, leverages weak supervision and consistency regularization to achieve robust results even with limited labeled data. Together, these models provide a comprehensive assessment of different segmentation approaches for urban environments in developing regions.DeepLabV3+DeepLabV3+ has been used for LULC segmentation in all experiments. It is a state-of-the-art semantic segmentation architecture developed by Google. DeepLabV332 by using an encoder-decoder structure and employing atrous (dilated) convolution50 to preserve spatial resolution while capturing multi-scale contextual information. The atrous convolution can be expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} y[i] = \sum _{k} x[i + r \cdot k] \cdot w[k] \end{aligned}$$where \(x\) is the input feature map, \(w\) is the convolutional kernel, \(r\) is the dilation rate, and \(i\) and \(k\) are spatial indices.We selected DeepLabV3+ due to its demonstrated effectiveness in supervised semantic segmentation tasks and its suitability for handling complex urban and rural landscapes in our LULC dataset. Benchmarking with DeepLabV3+ provided a solid baseline for comparison with other models like U-Net and UniMatch, ensuring that our analysis remains thorough and adaptable for future research.U-NetU-Net33 is a widely used architecture for semantic segmentation, known for its encoder-decoder structure with skip connections that help retain spatial detail. The skip connections combine low-level encoder features with decoder outputs and are expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} y_{\text {decoder}} = f_{\text {decoder}}(y_{\text {encoder}} \oplus y_{\text {skip}}) \end{aligned}$$where \(\oplus\) denotes concatenation. In our study, U-Net was used to benchmark segmentation performance against DeepLabV3+. The model performed competitively, particularly in built-up and meadow classes, and achieved strong average F1 scores. This confirms U-Net’s effectiveness as a reliable baseline for LULC segmentation.UniMatchUniMatch34 is a recent weakly supervised segmentation framework designed to leverage limited labeled data by enforcing consistency in model predictions under perturbations. Its consistency regularization can be expressed as:$$\begin{aligned} \mathcal {L}_{\text {consistency}} = \mathbb {E} \left[ \Vert p_{\theta }(x) - p_{\theta }(x') \Vert ^2 \right] \end{aligned}$$where \(p_{\theta }\) is the model’s prediction and \(x\) and \(x'\) are perturbed inputs. In our experiments, UniMatch demonstrated strong average IoU performance and competitive results in forest, built-up, water, and farmland classes, highlighting its robustness in LULC segmentation.Pre-processingThe input and ground truth images are divided into patches of size 513\(\times\)513 pixels for network training. Certain areas in the ground truth are difficult to label due to ambiguity or lack of information; these regions are marked as unrecognized and represented with black pixels in both the input and ground truth masks. For training, patches are extracted using a sliding window approach with 75% overlap in both horizontal and vertical directions to ensure sufficient coverage and context. During testing, non-overlapping patches are used. The paired input and ground truth patches are then fed into the DeepLabV3+ model for semantic segmentation.Evaluation metricsTo assess model performance, first, we calculate a confusion matrix51,52,53, which is an \(N \times N\) matrix, where N is the number of target classes. It is used for evaluating the performance of machine learning models. Each row of the matrix represents the instances in a predicted class, while each column represents the instances in an actual class (or vice versa).We derived the Intersection over Union (IoU) and the F1 score following the approach in46,54, which leads to a comprehensive evaluation. Both metrics were derived from confusion matrices constructed using predicted and ground truth pixel labels. These metrics offer a more balanced assessment compared to overall accuracy, particularly in the context of class imbalance commonly observed in LULC datasets.Intersection over Union (IoU) is defined as the ratio between the overlap area and the union area of the predicted and ground truth regions for each class:$$\begin{aligned} \text {IoU} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Positive} + \text {False Negative}} \end{aligned}$$This metric evaluates the spatial agreement between the predicted and actual land cover areas.F1 Score is the mean of precision and recall and provides a measure of a model’s accuracy by balancing both false positives and false negatives:$$\begin{aligned} \text {F1} = 2 \cdot \frac{\text {Precision} \cdot \text {Recall}}{\text {Precision} + \text {Recall}} \end{aligned}$$where:$$\begin{aligned} \text {Precision} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Positive}}, \quad \text {Recall} = \frac{\text {True Positive}}{\text {True Positive} + \text {False Negative}} \end{aligned}$$We excluded overall accuracy in our evaluation, since it can be misleading for imbalanced datasets where dominant classes often influence the metric despite poor performance on minority classes.Experiment setup & resultsExperiment settingsThe Dhaka city region (marked by the red rectangle in Fig. 3) is used as the test set, while areas outside this region but within the blue rectangle are used for training. Experiments are conducted using three types of input data: index images, channel-combined images, and Bing RGB images. All training images are generated using a 513\(\times\)513 sliding window with 75% overlap. A batch size of 8 and 25 training epochs was used across all experiments. Testing uses the same window size without overlap. DeepLabV3+ serves as the segmentation model for all the experiments but we employed U-net, UnimatchV2, HRNet-V2 and Segmenter ViT-16 only with the Bing RGB(BOLM) dataset for final comparison in Table 4. For index-based inputs, each index (NDVI, NDWI, RVI) is stacked into a 3-channel format. Channel-combination experiments use specific RGB arrangements from Sentinel-2 bands. The final experiment uses the full-resolution Bing imagery to assess segmentation accuracy at finer detail. In this section, we describe all the experimental results.Bing & sentinel-2A benchmark comparisonTable 3 Scores for 5 classes of all the image types.Full size tableThe segmentation results for the three index images (NDVI, NDWI, and RVI) and composite images (ATM, FCI, SWI, SentinelRGB) are shown in Table 3. These results highlight the strengths of each image type in segmenting the five LULC classes.Among the index images, NDWI achieves the highest IoU of 0.20 and F1 score of 0.32 for the forest class. It also performs best in detecting water, with an IoU of 0.24 and an F1 score of 0.51. NDVI shows the best performance for built-up and farmland classes, with an IoU of 0.52 and F1 score of 0.68 for built-up, and an IoU of 0.35 and F1 score of 0.51 for farmland. RVI has a slightly better F1 score for meadow at 0.52. While the average F1 scores of RVI and NDVI are similar, NDVI has a slightly higher average IoU of 0.30, suggesting it is the most balanced index image for overall land cover segmentation. NDWI, on the other hand, excels in water detection.For the composite images, SWI consistently achieves the highest average IoU and F1 scores of 0.35 and 0.50, respectively. SWI performs best for the forest class with an IoU of 0.22. Built-up areas are segmented equally well by ATM and SWI, with an IoU of 0.56, but SWI has slightly higher F1 scores, indicating better accuracy. Water is also segmented more accurately in SWI, while ATM shows the highest IoU for farmland at 0.48. For meadow, SentinelRGB achieves the highest IoU of 0.25.Overall, composite images outperform index images, likely due to the richer information provided by their three channels. Although SentinelRGB is commonly used for LULC mapping, it does not achieve the same performance as SWI and ATM. This suggests that combining different spectral indices and features in composite images helps achieve better class separability.The BingRGB dataset shows the highest performance among all datasets, with an average IoU of 0.44 and an average F1 score of 0.60. This indicates that the high-resolution RGB images from the Bing satellite contain more detailed information, leading to superior segmentation performance across all five LULC classes.To summarize, SWI emerges as the best composite image for Sentinel-2A data, with consistently high scores across most classes. NDVI stands out as the most balanced index image, while NDWI remains the best for detecting water. BingRGB, with its high-quality imagery, achieves the best overall segmentation results, highlighting the impact of data quality and resolution on classification accuracy.Baseline comparisonsFig. 9Normalized Confusion Matrices for DeepLabV3+, Segmenter ViT 16, U-Net, and UniMatchV2.Full size imageWe have included normalized confusion matrices for each baseline model, following the approach adopted in recent literature51,52,53, to provide a detailed assessment of class-wise segmentation performance. The Fig. 9 presents normalized confusion matrices comparing the performance of DeepLabV3+, Segmenter ViT 16, U-Net, and UniMatchV2 on land use and land cover (LULC) classification. UniMatchV2 and U-Net show relatively balanced performance across all classes, with U-Net achieving strong discrimination in built-up and water regions. DeepLabV3+ shows higher misclassification in forest and meadow categories, often confusing them with built-up and farmland. All models maintain perfect classification for the unrecognized class. Overall, UniMatchV2 demonstrates slightly better consistency in forest and farmland segmentation, while U-Net maintains high accuracy in built-up and water classes.The confusion matrices in Fig. 9 show two major misclassification patterns that are consistent across all four models. First, there is a significant confusion between meadow and farmland. This happens because it is often difficult for even advanced deep learning models to distinguish between the two, especially in early crop seasons when farmlands appear barren and resemble natural meadows. However, our in-situ assessments confirmed that the ground truth labels were correct in those cases. Second, there is noticeable overlap between built-up and forest classes. This is particularly common in Dhaka city, where rooftop gardens are widespread, and in rural areas where trees often lean over the roofs of single-story houses. These subtle and small-scale features are difficult for the models to classify accurately.The results in Table 4 reveal that UniMatchV2 achieves the best overall performance with the highest average IoU of 0.51. It also leads in the forest, built-up and water classes, demonstrating strong segmentation across major LULC classes. U-Net shows competitive results, particularly excelling in F1 scores for built-up (0.81), water (0.73), and meadow (0.43). U-Net also achieves the best IoU for meadow at 0.30 and an average F1 score of 0.65, which is higher than DeeplabV3+. The Segmenter ViT-16 did best on the farmland class with merginal improvements over the UnimatchV2 and very similar on the built-up class.Table 4 Performance comparison of DeeplabV3+, U-Net, UniMatchV2, Segmenter ViT-16, and HRNet on different LULC classes.Full size tableDeeplabV3+ delivers solid and consistent segmentation, with an average IoU of 0.44 and an F1 score of 0.60. While it does not outperform the other models in individual classes, it remains a reliable option for general land cover mapping. Overall, UniMatchV2 emerges as the best-performing model in IoU scores, while U-Net shows a balanced and precise segmentation ability, particularly in challenging classes like meadow. These findings highlight the strengths of each method in different aspects of LULC segmentation.LULC comparison with world bankTable 5 Classification results for different train and test data combinations using DeepLabV3+. The highest values per column are highlighted.Full size tableThe results in Table 5 show class-wise and mean Intersection over Union (IoU) scores for different train and test combinations using the BOLM and World Bank datasets. The highest values for each class are highlighted. The model trained and tested on the BOLM dataset achieves the highest mean IoU of 0.49 and outperforms all other combinations in forest, water, and farmland categories. When evaluated on the World Bank test set, the BOLM-trained model still performs reasonably well, achieving a mean IoU of 0.43. In contrast, the model trained on the World Bank dataset yields lower mean IoUs of 0.20 on BOLM and 0.30 on its own test set. Note that Forest values are marked as N/A for World Bank training scenarios due to the absence of forest annotations in that dataset.LULC for full BangladeshAfter training the DeeplabV3+ model, we are now able to generate detailed LULC maps for the entire country of Bangladesh. Figure 10 presents LULC predictions for three example districts: Cox’s Bazar, Rangamati, and Netrokona. The model differentiates major land cover classes, including built-up areas, water bodies, forests, farmland, and meadows. For each district, the LULC distribution is visualized, highlighting the strong capability of the model to provide accurate and detailed land cover information at the district level. These predictions show the potential of the trained model to support large-scale mapping and analysis of LULC across Bangladesh.Fig. 10Prediction of (a) Cox’s Bazar, (b) Rangamati and (c) Netrokona districts using our trained model on DeepLabV3+. Map created by the authors using data from31.Full size imageDiscussionWe conducted a series of experiments to benchmark model performance using our annotated dataset. The annotated labels were found to be sufficient for training large-scale deep learning models with reliable accuracy. Initially, Sentinel-2A images with various band combinations and index-based transformations (e.g., NDVI, NDWI) were used with our ground truth to evaluate model performance on low-resolution data (10 to 20 meters/pixel). Subsequently, Bing imagery was used to test high-resolution input. Results showed that segmentation performance with Bing images consistently outperformed Sentinel-2A experiments.These findings highlight practical considerations for the remote sensing community in developing countries. Our annotated dataset can be used with both high-resolution RGB imagery (e.g., Bing, Google) and freely available lower-resolution multispectral satellite data (e.g., Sentinel-2A), depending on the application’s requirements. High-resolution imagery is preferable when accuracy is critical (e.g., for urban expansion or annual land cover change detection). However, due to limited temporal availability and access restrictions of commercial platforms in developing countries, lower-resolution Sentinel-2A data may be more suitable for tasks requiring frequent monitoring, such as crop analysis55.It is also important to note that Bing and Google imagery only provide RGB channels and do not include near-infrared (NIR) or shortwave infrared (SWIR) bands. As a result, common remote sensing indices like NDVI and NDWI cannot be calculated from these sources. To address this, our annotations can be paired with Sentinel-2A imagery that includes spectral bands for calculating such indices, enabling broader LULC applications.Although Bing imagery offers very high spatial resolution, it has significant limitations in both metadata transparency and temporal coverage, especially in developing countries. This reduces its effectiveness for applications that require regular temporal monitoring or change detection. Lesiv et al56. conducted a comprehensive analysis of Bing and Google Earth imagery and found that their update frequency is inconsistent and often delayed by several years in less economically prioritized regions. Additionally, Bing imagery provides only RGB bands, lacking crucial spectral information such as near-infrared (NIR) and shortwave infrared (SWIR), which are essential for distinguishing between spectrally similar land cover types. In contrast, multispectral data from platforms like Sentinel-2 offer higher spectral resolution and regular temporal updates, enabling more accurate LULC classification57. Khaldi et al58. further emphasize that multispectral time series are critical for capturing seasonal variability and long-term land cover trends, highlighting a key shortcoming of RGB-only imagery such as Bing. Since the BOLM dataset is georeferenced, it can be readily aligned with Sentinel-2 or other multispectral datasets acquired at matching time periods. This enables researchers to take advantage of BOLM’s fine spatial detail while complementing it with spectral and temporal insights from other platforms, thereby extending the dataset’s applicability to broader LULC and environmental analysis tasks. Despite the inherent spectral and temporal limitations of Bing, its high-resolution imagery remains highly valuable for fine-grained annotation and urban structure delineation, especially in dense and heterogeneous regions where lower-resolution imagery fails to capture critical detail.Bing imagery was chosen as the primary source for annotation due to its higher spatial resolution, which is essential for distinguishing fine-scale land cover features in densely populated urban environments like Dhaka. Although Bing provides only RGB bands, prior studies (e.g., Ramos et al.46) have shown that high-resolution RGB imagery can achieve competitive segmentation accuracy, particularly when detailed pixel-level annotations are available. While Sentinel-2 offers multispectral data and higher temporal frequency, its 10–20 m resolution is insufficient for capturing fine-grained urban heterogeneity. Moreover, as Brown et al.49 demonstrated, expert annotations guided by RGB imagery (including Google Earth) can support reliable land cover mapping even without full spectral information, provided that spatial detail and acquisition date alignment are maintained.In our study, the Bing imagery used for annotation was captured in April 2019. To mitigate the issue of infrequent updates, we cross-validated the imagery against historical Google Earth data from the same period. This helped verify temporal consistency and detect areas with recent land use changes. Ambiguous or recently modified regions (e.g., under construction) were excluded or labeled as “Unrecognized” to avoid introducing noise into the training data. While Bing’s update frequency limits its use for time-series monitoring, its spatial precision makes it highly suitable for baseline mapping and detailed model training in data-scarce regions.BOLM’s high-resolution imagery and detailed, pixel-level annotations enable better class separation and generalization, especially in complex urban-rural environments like Dhaka city. While the World Bank-trained model reports a higher IoU for the Built-up class, this is partly due to a trade-off: the dataset lacks a Forest or Tree class, which removes the ambiguity between vegetation and built-up areas. As a result, many vegetated regions near urban zones are misclassified as Built-up (shown in supplementary figure S1), artificially inflating the score. If a Forest class were included, the model’s ability to distinguish these overlapping features would be significantly challenged, especially given the coarse annotation style and limited class definitions in the World Bank dataset. In contrast, BOLM explicitly defines such classes, allowing the model to learn finer distinctions between urban structures and surrounding vegetation, an essential capability in unstructured and densely mixed land use settings common in developing countries.Both Bing and Sentinel-2 imagery serve complementary roles when used with the BOLM dataset, depending on the application focus. For monitoring, time-series analysis, and remote sensing applications, Sentinel-2 can be aligned with BOLM’s georeferenced annotations to leverage its rich spectral bands and frequent temporal coverage. This is particularly effective for tracking seasonal land cover changes, assessing vegetation health, or conducting disaster resilience studies using spectral indices like NDVI and NDWI. In contrast, for deep learning benchmarks and tasks aligned with the computer vision community, BOLM paired with Bing’s high-resolution RGB imagery is better suited. The fine spatial detail of Bing facilitates pixel-level segmentation, feature learning, and model evaluation for urban environments, where detailed object boundaries are crucial and multispectral information is not a requirement. This contrast highlights BOLM’s flexibility across disciplines: supporting vision-based model development on Bing imagery, while also enabling spectral-temporal analyses when paired with Sentinel-2, thus broadening its utility in both computer vision and remote sensing research.The findings of Rahman et al.23 highlight challenges in applying this dataset to other regions due to differences in building materials, urban patterns, and settlement textures. For example, informal areas in Dhaka differ in appearance from those in Cairo or Mumbai, leading to varied segmentation performance across cities. Models like DeepLabv3+ perform best when trained and tested on the same city but may struggle to generalize to cities with distinct urban morphologies. This underscores the need for domain-adaptive methods to ensure consistent segmentation performance in cross-city applications.The model was first trained and tested on Sentinel and RGB datasets using DeeplabV3+ to understand if Bing RGB data offers better segmentation performance. In Table 4, we compared different baselines, including U-Net, Segmenter ViT-16 and the weakly supervised UniMatch model. This comparison aimed to see whether the segmentation scores could be improved using other models. The results show that standard benchmarks like U-Net perform very well, and even weakly supervised approaches such as UniMatch demonstrate strong performance. Although this study focuses on DeeplabV3+ to explore the benefits of atrous convolution for capturing spatial detail, the findings remain model-agnostic. Any better-performing model can be integrated into this workflow for improved results. Considering that newer transformer-based models are capable of capturing global context more effectively, future research can explore these architectures to build more robust segmentation models for LULC mapping.ConclusionThis paper provides high-resolution pixel-wise LULC ground truth annotations for Dhaka metropolitan city and its surrounding area. It covers an area of around 4392 square kilometers of the Dhaka region centered at Dhaka metropolitan city. This BOLM dataset can serve as LULC ground truth for eleven classes(eleven classes: Farmland, Water, Forest, Urban Structure, Urban Built-Up, Rural Built-Up, Road, Meadow, Marshland, Brick Factory, Unrecognized) for a developing country. It contains both rural & urban areas. Additionally, several experiments have been performed to establish baseline performance with Bing and Sentinel 2 A data for five major LULC classes: forest, farmland, builtup, water, & meadow. As Sentinel 2 A provides multi-channel data, index images, and different combination images are also used for our experiments for LULC. The investigation suggests that Bing data consistently outperformed the Sentinel 2 A data in any form with a significant margin. However, if the high-resolution image is not available, short-wave infrared (SWI) from Sentinel 2 should be used to get the best performance with the deep models.The BOLM dataset holds strong potential to support future advancements in land use and land cover harmonization as well as global urban mapping research. Its high-resolution pixel-level annotations offer a valuable benchmark for deep learning models across diverse geographic and socio-economic contexts. By aligning BOLM with multispectral sources such as Sentinel-2, researchers can integrate fine spatial detail with rich spectral information, enabling consistent cross-regional classification and temporal monitoring. This interoperability facilitates the development of standardized LULC products that are essential for harmonization efforts across developing and developed regions. Furthermore, BOLM’s detailed representation of heterogeneous urban and peri-urban environments provides a robust foundation for refining global urban mapping algorithms, improving their adaptability to unstructured landscapes, and enhancing the accuracy of urban extent and growth assessments worldwide.

Data availability
              
              This dataset has been made available online here under the Creative Common (CC) license. Te direct link is:https://doi.org/10.7910/DVN/LLR3RR.
            Code availability
              
              Custom codes were written to process this dataset. The RGB image is required to convert into an Index image as it is required in the architecture. Also, to enhance the performance of the model and eliminate possible confusion from the dataset, the unknown part of the label needs to be projected on the input image. If the paper is accepted, the link for the codes will be published here.

I due uccelli facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, finanziato dall’Unione Europea
The post Ancora due Ibis eremita uccisi a fucilate appea
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Il bracconaggio continua a decimare una specie vicina all’estinzione Due Ibis eremita (Geronticus eremita), appartenenti ad una specie in pericolo critico di estinzione — scomparsi in Europa nel XVII secolo e reintrodotti grazie a un progetto di conservazione LIFE riconosciuto a livello mondiale — sono stati abbattuti il 16 ottobre a Dubino (Provincia di Sondrio, Lombardia), poco dopo aver attraversato il confine durante la migrazione. Un intervento immediato da parte delle autorità è stato possibile grazie alla stretta collaborazione tra l’associazione Waldrappteam, che gestisce il progetto, i Carabinieri Forestali e la Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola.I due Ibis, Zoppo e Zaz, facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, che vede Natura Viva come suo unico partner italiano ed è finanziato dall’Unione Europea. Si tratta infatti della prima iniziativa al mondo volta a ristabilire una specie migratrice nel suo storico areale europeo, ripristinando un comportamento migratorio culturale ormai perduto. Dal 2004, giovani Ibis allevati dall’uomo vengono guidati dalle colonie riproduttive che si trovano a nord delle Alpi fino al sito di svernamento in Toscana (Oasi WWF di Orbetello), assicurando che imparino la rotta migratoria per i viaggi futuri. La storia dei due Ibis Zoppo era un pionere tra questi uccelli. Nel 2017 aveva seguito con successo un ultraleggero da Überlingen, attraversando le Alpi fino all’Italia. Nel 2020 era diventato il primo Ibis eremita sessualmente maturo, dopo oltre 400 anni, a tornare indipendentemente nel sito di riproduzione sul Lago di Costanza. Un traguardo di inestimabile importanza per la creazione di una nuova colonia europea. Zaz, nata in natura a Überlingen nel maggio 2025, stava imparando quest’anno la rotta migratoria proprio da Zoppo — seguendolo passo dopo passo nel suo primo viaggio verso sud. All’inizio di ottobre 2025, la coppia aveva lasciato il sito riproduttivo ed era entrata in Svizzera, tentando più volte di attraversare le Alpi nel Cantone dei Grigioni. Il 16 ottobre, erano finalmente riusciti a superare la dorsale alpina principale nei pressi del Piz Gallagiun, a quasi 3.000 metri di altitudine. Poco dopo, si erano posati in un prato nei pressi di Dubino per cercare cibo — e sono stati uccisi a fucilate meno di un’ora dopo essere entrati in Italia. Petizione caccia Firma anche tu per dire Stop alla caccia selvaggia Aderisci all'appello Quasi tutti gli Ibis eremita del Progetto sono equipaggiati di trasmettitori GPS, che ne consentono il monitoraggio in tempo reale. Ciò ha permesso a Waldrappteam di allertare immediatamente le autorità. I Carabinieri Forestali di Lecco e Sondrio, con il supporto della Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola, hanno avviato un’indagine approfondita e recuperato i trasmettitori dei due Ibis. Sono stati sequestrati armi, munizioni, dispositivi elettronici ed una licenza di caccia ad un sospettato, che ora dovrà rispondere di accuse tra cui uccisione di fauna protetta e possesso illegale di armi. Ibis eremita in volo Il bracconaggio mette a rischio specie già minacciate Dure condanne arrivano anche dai vertici del mondo della conservazione.“Il bracconaggio resta la minaccia più grave per l’Ibis eremita in Italia,”ha affermato il Dr. Johannes Fritz, Direttore di Waldrappteam Conservation & Research. “L’uccisione di due Ibis eremita a meno di un’ora dal loro arrivo in Italia è un promemoria doloroso della grave minaccia che il bracconaggio rappresenta per la biodiversità e dell’urgenza di combattere questo crimine.”L’episodio avviene in un momento di forte preoccupazione riguardo al Disegno di Legge 1552, una proposta legislativa italiana che mira ad estendere la stagione venatoria anche a periodi cruciali per le specie migratrici.Un grazie ai Carabinieri Forestali ed alla Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola per la loro azione rapida e professionale. Questo caso evidenzia l’importanza della collaborazione coordinata tra organizzazioni di conservazione, forze dell’ordine, autorità e volontari — in linea con l’Articolo 9 della Costituzione italiana, che impegna la Repubblica a proteggere la natura e la biodiversità per le generazioni future.
